tn.text: These verses give background information about Jesus' preaching while traveling.
This phrase is used here to mark a new part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: who had been healed of evil spirits and diseases
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom Jesus had set free from evil spirits and healed of diseases" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Three of the women are listed: Mary, Joanna, and Susanna. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: seven demons had been driven out
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus had driven out seven demons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's manager
tn.text: Joanna was Chuza's wife, and Chuza was Herod's manager. "Joanna, the wife of Herod's manager, Chuza" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"financially supported Jesus and his twelve disciples"
Jesus tells the parable of the soils to the crowd. He explains its meaning to his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
"coming to Jesus"

tn.ref: A farmer went out to sow his seed
tn.text: "A farmer went out to scatter some seeds in a field"
"some of the seed fell" or "some of the seeds fell"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "people walked on it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This idiom can be translated simply as "birds" or  as "birds flew down and" to keep the sense of "sky."
"ate it all"
"the plants became dry and shriveled up"
"they were too dry." The cause can also be stated. AT: "the ground was too dry"
Jesus finishes telling the parable to the crowd.
The thorn plants took all the nutrients, water, and sunlight, so the farmer's plants could not grow well.
"grew a harvest" or "grew more seeds"
This means a hundred times more than the seeds that were sown. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear
tn.text: It may be more natural in some languages to use the second person: "You who have ears to hear, hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Possible meanings are 1) "Everyone" since everyone has ears or 2) "Whoever has the ability to understand" which refers to those who are willing to listen to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"he should listen well" or "he should pay attention to what I say"
Jesus begins to speak to his disciples.

tn.ref: The knowledge of ... God has been given to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has given to you the knowledge of ... God" or "God has made you able to understand ... God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the secrets of the kingdom of God
tn.text: These are truths that had been hidden, but Jesus was now revealing them.
"for other people." This refers to the people who rejected the teaching of Jesus and did not follow him.

"though they see, they will not perceive." This is a quote from the prophet Isaiah. Some languages may need to state the object of the verbs. AT: "though they see things, they will not understand them" or "though they see things happen, they will not understand what they mean"

"though they hear, they will not understand." This is a quote from the prophet Isaiah. Some languages may need to state the object of the verbs. AT: "though they hear instruction, they will not understand the truth"
Jesus begins to explain the meaning of the parable of the soils to his disciples.

tn.ref: the seed is the word of God
tn.text: "the seed represents the word of God"

tn.ref: The ones along the path are
tn.text: "the seeds that fell along the path." Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds along the path" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell along the path" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus speaks of the seeds showing something about people as if the seeds were the people. AT: "show what happens to people who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts
tn.text: This means that he causes them to forget the word of God that they have heard.
In the parable this was a metaphor of a bird snatching away the seeds. Try to use words in your language that keep that image. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: so they may not believe and be saved
tn.text: Since this is the devil's purpose, it can be translated as: AT: "because the devil thinks, 'They must not believe and they must not be saved'" or "so they will not believe with the result that God saves them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

"the seeds that fell on the rocky soil." Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds on the rocky soil" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell on the rocky soil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the rocky soil"
"when they experience hardship"
This idiom means "they stop believing" or "they stop following Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: The seeds that fell among the thorns
tn.text: Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds that fell among the thorns" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell among the thorns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus speaks of the seeds showing something about people as if the seeds were the people. AT: "show what happens to people who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they are choked ... pleasures of this life
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the cares and riches and pleasures of this life choke them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the things that people worry about"
"the things in this life that people enjoy"

tn.ref: they are choked by ... pleasures of this life
tn.text: This metaphor refers to the way weeds cut off light and nutrients from plants and keep them from growing. AT: "as weeds prevent good plants from growing, the cares, riches, and pleasures of this life keep these people from becoming mature" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"they do not bear ripe fruit." Mature fruit is a metaphor for good works. AT: "so like a plant does not produce mature fruit, they do not produce good works" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the seed that fell on the good soil
tn.text: Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds that fell on the good soil" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell on the good soil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus speaks of the seeds showing something about people as if the seeds were the people. AT: "show what happens to people who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"produce fruit by enduring patiently" or "produce fruit by continued effort." Fruit is a metaphor for good works. AT: "like healthy plants that produce good fruit, they produce good works by persevering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jesus continues with another parable then he finishes speaking to his disciples as he emphasizes the role of his family in his work.
This marks the beginning of another parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: nothing is hidden that will not be made known
tn.text: This double-negative can be written as a positive statement. AT: "everything that is hidden will be made known" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: nor is anything secret that will not be known and come into the light
tn.text: This double-negative can be written as a positive statement. AT: "and everything that is secret will be made known and will come into the light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: to the one who has, more will be given to him
tn.text: It is clear from the context that Jesus is talking about understanding and believing. This can be stated clearly and changed to active form. AT: "whoever has understanding will be given more understanding" or "God will enable those who believe the truth to understand even more"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the one who does not have ... will be taken away from him
tn.text: It is clear from the context that Jesus is talking about understanding and believing. This can be stated clearly and changed to active form. AT: "But whoever does not have understanding will lose even what understanding he thinks he has" or "But God will cause those who do not believe the truth not to understand even the little that they think they have understood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

These were Jesus' younger brothers—the other sons of Mary and Joseph who were born after Jesus. Since the Father of Jesus was God, and their father was Joseph, they were technically his half-brothers. This detail is not normally translated.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People told him" or "Someone told him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"and they want to see you"

tn.ref: My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God and do it
tn.text: This metaphor expresses that the people who were coming to listen to Jesus were as important to him as his own family was. AT: "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are like a mother and brothers to me" or "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are as important to me as my mother and brothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jesus and his disciples then use a boat to cross Lake Genneseret. The disciples learn more about Jesus' power through the storm that arises.
This is the lake of Genneseret which is also called the Sea of Galilee.
This expression means they began to travel across the lake in their sailboat.
"as they went"
"slept"
"a storm of very strong winds began" or "very strong winds suddenly began to blow"

tn.ref: their boat was filling with water
tn.text: The strong winds caused high waves which pushed water over the sides of the boat. This can be stated clearly. AT: "the winds caused high waves that started to fill up their boat with water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"spoke sharply to"
"the violent waves" (UDB)
"the wind and the waves stopped" or "they became still" (UDB)

Jesus was rebuking them mildly because they did not trust him to take care of them. This can be written as a statement. AT: "You should have had faith" or "You should have trusted me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Who then is this ... obey him?
tn.text: "What kind of man is this ... obey him?" This question expresses the shock and confusion over how Jesus was able to control the storm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be the beginning of a new sentence: "He commands"
Jesus and his disciples come ashore at Gerasa where Jesus removes many demons from a man.
Gerasenes were people from the city called Gerasa. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"on the other side of the lake from Galilee"

tn.ref: a certain man from the city
tn.text: "a man from the city of Gerasa"

tn.ref: a certain man from the city who had demons
tn.text: The man had demons; it was not the city that had demons. AT: "a certain man from the city, and this man had demons"
"who was controlled by demons" or "whom demons controlled"

tn.ref: For a long time he had worn no clothes ... but among the tombs
tn.text: This is background information about the man who had demons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"he had not worn clothes"
These are places where people put dead bodies, possibly caves or small buildings that the man could use for shelter.
"When the man who had the demon saw Jesus"
"he screamed" or "he shrieked"
"lay down on the ground before Jesus." He did not fall accidentally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: he said with a loud voice
tn.text: "He said loudly" or "He shouted out"

tn.ref: What have you to do with me
tn.text: This idiom means "Why are you bothering me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Son of the Most High God
tn.text: This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: many times it had seized him
tn.text: "many times it had taken control of the man" or "many times it had gone into him." This tells about what the demon had done many times before Jesus met the man.

tn.ref: hough he was bound ... and kept under guard
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "though the people had bound him with chains and shackles and guarded him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the demon would make him go out" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Translate this with a word that refers to a large number of soldiers or people. Some other translations say "Army." AT: "Battalion" or "Brigade"
"kept begging Jesus"

tn.ref: Now a large herd of pigs was there feeding on the hillside
tn.text: This is supplied as background information to introduce the pigs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: was there feeding on the hillside
tn.text: "was nearby eating grass on a hill"
The word "so" is used here to explain that the reason the demons came of out the man was because Jesus had told them that they could go into the pigs.
"ran very fast"

tn.ref: found the man from whom the demons had gone out
tn.text: "saw the man whom the demons had left"
"and sane" or "and behaving normally"

tn.ref: sitting at the feet of Jesus
tn.text: "sitting at the feet" is an idiom that means "sitting humbly nearby" or "sitting in front of." AT: "sitting on the ground in front of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"they were afraid of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"those who had seen what had happened"

tn.ref: the man who had been controlled by demons had been healed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus had healed the man that demons had controlled"(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"that area of the Gerasenes" or "the area where the Gerasene people lived"

tn.ref: they were overwhelmed with great fear
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they became very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The destination can be stated. AT: "go back across the lake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

The events in these verses happened before Jesus left in the boat. It may be helpful to state this clearly at the beginning. AT: "Before Jesus and his disciples left, the man" or "Before Jesus and his disciples set sail, the man"
"your household" or "your family"

tn.ref: give a full account of what God has done for you
tn.text: "and tell them everything about what God has done for you"
When Jesus and his disciples return to Galilee on the other side of the lake, he heals the 12 year old daughter of the ruler of the synagogue as well as a woman who has been bleeding for 12 years.
These verses give background information about Jairus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"the crowd joyfully greeted him"

tn.ref: one of the leaders of the synagogue
tn.text: "one of the leaders at the local synagogue" or "a leader of the people who met at the synagogue in that city"

Possible meanings are 1) "bowed down at Jesus feet" or 2) "lay down on the ground at Jesus feet." Jairus did not fall accidentally. He did this as a sign of humility and respect for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"was about to die"

tn.ref: As Jesus was on his way
tn.text: Some translators may need to first say that Jesus had agreed to go with Jairus. AT: "So Jesus agreed to go with him. As he was on his way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the crowds of people pressed together around him
tn.text: "the people were crowding tightly around Jesus"
This introduces a new character in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

"had a flow of blood." She was probably bleeding from her womb even when it was not the normal time for it. Some cultures may have a polite way of referring to this condition. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: but could not be healed by any of them
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but none of them could cure her" or "but none of them could heal her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: touched the edge of his coat
tn.text: "touched the fringe of his robe." Jewish men wore tassels on the edges of their robes as a part of their ceremonial dress as commanded in God's Law. This is likely what she touched.

tn.ref: the crowds of people ... are pressing in against you
tn.text: By saying this, Peter was implying that anyone could have touched Jesus. This implicit information can be made explicit if necessary. AT: "there are many people crowding around you and pressing in against you, so any one of them might have touched you!" (UDB) (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It may be helpful to distinguish this intentional "touch" from the accidental touches of the crowd. AT: "I know that someone deliberately touched me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I know that power has gone out from me
tn.text: Jesus did not lose power or become weak, but his power healed the woman. AT: "I know that healing power went out from me" or "I felt my power heal someone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: that she could not escape notice
tn.text: "that she could not keep secret what she had done." It may be helpful to state what she did. AT: "that she could not keep it a secret that she was the one who had touched Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"she came trembling with fear"
Possible meanings are 1) "She bowed down in front of Jesus" or 2) "She lay down on the ground at Jesus' feet." She did not fall accidentally. This was a sign of humility and respect for Jesus.
"in the sight of" or "among"
This was a kind way of speaking to a woman. Your language may have another way of showing this kindness.

tn.ref: your faith has made you well
tn.text: "because of your faith, you have become well." "faith" could be stated as an action. AT: "because you believe, you are healed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

This idiom is a way of saying, "Goodbye" and giving a blessing at the same time. AT: "As you go, do not worry anymore" or "May God give you peace as you go" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"While Jesus was still speaking to the woman"
This refers to Jairus. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:luk:08:40|8:41]])
This statement implies that Jesus will not be able to do anything to help now that the girl is dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to Jesus.
"she will be well" or "she will live again" (UDB).

tn.ref: When he came to the house
tn.text: "When they came to the house." Jesus went their with Jairus. Also some of Jesus' disciples went with them.

tn.ref: he allowed no one ... except Peter and John and James, and the father of the child and her mother
tn.text: This could be stated positively. AT: "Jesus allowed only Peter, John, and James, and the girl's father and mother to go inside with him"
This refers to Jairus.

tn.ref: all were mourning and wailing for her
tn.text: This was the normal way of showing grief in that culture. AT: "all the people there were showing how sad they were and crying loudly because the girl had died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"because they knew the girl was dead" (UDB)

tn.ref: he, taking the girl by the hand
tn.text: "Jesus took hold of the girl's hand"
"Little girl, get up"

"Her spirit returned to her body." The Jews understood that life was the result of the spirit coming into a person. AT: "She came back to life" or "She became alive again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"breath" or "life"

tn.ref: that something be given to her to eat
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that they give her something to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This could be stated differently. AT: "not to tell anyone"
